title: SoftBank-backed Compass tells employees: We're not WeWork
text:
WeWork's calamitous effort to take itself public raised red flags for other SoftBank-backed real estate startups – leading an executive at Compass to send its employees an eight-point memo highlighting the differences between the two firms.

Compass, like WeWork, relied heavily on funding from SoftBank's Vision Fund. The brokerage has become a major player in high-end markets like Manhattan and San Francisco, though some real estate experts argue it's more like a traditional property brokerage than a tech-industry disrupter.

The collapse of the WeWork IPO has put focus on other SoftBank-backed companies. Getty Images

Unlike WeWork, Compass has no debt and is valued at a revenue multiple comparable to publicly traded real estate technology companies, according to chief financial officer Kristen Ankerbrandt.

"Over the past few weeks, we have seen comparisons being drawn between Compass and WeWork simply because we share a single investor," Ms Ankerbrandt wrote to employees last week in an email obtained by Bloomberg. "To be clear, our businesses are quite different – in terms of our business model, capital structure, customers, culture and investments."

Ms Ankerbrandt also boasted of Compass's deep roster of investors, including Qatar Investment Authority and Dragoneer Investment Group; a 425-member tech team building tools to differentiate Compass from other brokerages; and a frugal leadership team that "books coach tickets and does not fly on private jets".
description: WeWork's calamitous effort to take itself public raised red flags for other SoftBank-backed real estate startups.
